The Bodhisattva has ten dharmas that abide in, which are explained equally by the Buddhas of the past, future, and present.

First, what is meant by the stage of abiding in the Dharma of the PrativedhanÄdharman Bodhisattvas?

At the top, seeing the Buddha's upright appearance, unparalleled, looking at his complexion without any weariness, none can surpass him, none can surpass his noble status, none can surpass his flying, none can surpass his teachings.

This bodhisattva sees the Buddha's majestic demeanor and Dharma like this, causing him to gradually enter the Buddha's path and turn to guiding others, all according to his intentions, teaching and liberating them.
Having seen those who suffer, he has compassion for them all, gradually becoming more familiar with the Buddha's words and believing in them.
Those who newly give rise to the intention to study the Buddha's path all wish to attain the Buddha's wisdom in the ten difficult places, all wish to attain the ten kinds of powers.
The bodhisattva's teachings have ten matters.
What are the ten matters?

First, they should make offerings to the Buddhas and bodhisattvas; second, they should teach according to the inclinations of others; third, wherever they are born, they will be respected; fourth, there will be none in the heavens and the human realm who can surpass them; fifth, they will attain all the wisdom possessed by the Buddhas; sixth, wherever they are born in the world, they will always see innumerable Buddhas; seventh, they will attain all the profound samadhi sutras; eighth, they will come from a place with boundless life and death; ninth, their lifespan will not be short; and tenth, they will completely liberate the people of the ten directions.
Why is this?
Because they enter deeply into the Buddha Dharma.
Second, what are the ten intentions of the bodhisattvas abiding in the stage of Acalana?
They contemplate the people of the ten directions.
What are the ten intentions?

First, to think of the goodness of all worldly people; second, to have a pure mind; third, to have a mind of peace and security; fourth, to have a soft and gentle mind; fifth, to love all equally; sixth, to think in the mind only of giving to others; seventh, to protect all in the mind; eighth, to think in the mind that others are no different from one's own body; ninth, to think in the mind of the people of the ten directions as one observes them like teachers; tenth, to think in the mind of the people of the ten directions as one views them like the Buddha.
Ajita Bodhisattva's Dharma is to study the sutras extensively;
Having studied the sutras extensively, one should dwell in solitude;

Having studied and entered into wisdom, one should uphold all the teachings one has received;
Having upheld the teachings, one should not forget them;
Having not forgotten them, one should abide in peace and security.
Why is this so?
It is because one has compassion for the people of the ten directions.
Third, what are the practices of the bodhisattva Yu Ajana?
One enters into all dharmas using ten things.
What are the ten things?

First, all that exists is impermanent; second, all that exists is suffering; third, all that exists is empty; fourth, all that exists is not mine; fifth, all that exists has no abode; sixth, all that exists is without benefit; seventh, all that exists has no resting place; eighth, all that exists has no location; ninth, all that exists is unattached; tenth, all that exists is non-existent. All dharmas enter this and do not return.

For this reason, one should illuminate the Dharma.

First, not returning; second, having deep compassion for the Buddha; third, deeply contemplating the Dharma; fourth, viewing all people in the ten directions with a compassionate mind; fifth, contemplating the ten directions as being empty of anything; sixth, the Buddha lands in the ten directions are all empty space; seventh, past lives and actions are empty of anything; eighth, all that exists is empty like an illusion; ninth, all suffering is nonexistent; tenth, nirvana is empty space and nonexistent.

From where do the thoughts of the Dharma of past Buddhas arise?
Searching, they are found to be non-existent;
From where do the thoughts of the Dharma of future Buddhas arise?
Searching, they are found to be non-existent;
From where do the thoughts of the Dharma of present Buddhas arise?
Searching, they are found to be non-existent.
The Dharmas of all Buddhas are all understood to be non-existent.
Why is this?
These Dharmas of the three times are all understood to be non-existent, one.
Fifth, what are the five dharmas of the bodhisattva stage of abodes?
The merits one creates all deliver the people of the ten directions, there are ten things.
What are the ten things?

First, to protect all people in the ten directions; second, to make all people in the ten directions wholesome; third, to think of the peaceful and secure lives of all people in the ten directions; fourth, to love all people in the ten directions; fifth, to have compassion for all people in the ten directions; sixth, to teach all people in the ten directions not to do evil; seventh, to lead all people in the ten directions into the path of the bodhisattvas; eighth, to purify all people in the ten directions; ninth, to liberate all people in the ten directions; tenth, to deliver all people in the ten directions and cause them to attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.

The people in the ten directions are incalculable, the people in the ten directions are innumerable, the people in the ten directions are inconceivable, the people in the ten directions are immeasurable, the people in the ten directions are beyond measure, and the people in the ten directions are beyond description.
What are the people in the ten directions?
All people in the ten directions are empty people, all are not my people, all are people without self, all have, all are without other wonders.
Why is it so?
Because the mind is unattached.

First, whether praising or criticizing the Buddha, the mind remains unchanged; second, whether praising or criticizing the Dharma, the mind remains unchanged; third, whether praising or criticizing the bodhisattvas, the mind remains unchanged; fourth, whether discussing the good or bad of those who seek the bodhisattva path, the mind remains unchanged; fifth, whether someone says that there are many or few people in the ten directions, the mind remains unchanged; sixth, whether discussing the good or bad of all people in the ten directions, the mind remains unchanged;
seventh, even if some say that people in the ten directions are easy to deliver or difficult to deliver, their minds remain unchanged;
eighth, even if they speak much Dharma or little Dharma,
their minds remain unchanged; ninth, even if the Dharma they speak is destroyed or not destroyed, their minds remain
unchanged; tenth, even if there is a place with Dharma or a place without Dharma, their minds remain unchanged.
This bodhisattva should study these dharmas without any place.
There are also ten things.
What are the ten things?

First, all dharmas have no place; second, all dharmas cannot be seen; third, learning all dharmas is like an illusion; fourth, all dharmas are empty; fifth, all dharmas are of various kinds of emptiness; sixth, all dharmas are unobstructed, reaching the ultimate emptiness; seventh, all dharmas are like magical transformations; eighth, all dharmas are like things in a dream; ninth, all dharmas are incalculable; tenth, all dharmas are nonexistent and cannot be seen.
Why is it so?
They become even more deeply immersed in the Buddha Dharma, with no one able to surpass them.
Seventh, what are the dharmas that the irreversible bodhisattvas abide in?
The bodhisattvas hear ten things and firmly abide in them.
What are the ten things?

This bodhisattva should be taught to study these ten things.
What are the ten?

First, entering various wisdoms from a single wisdom; second, entering a single wisdom from various wisdoms; third, a single wisdom entering various matters; fourth, entering a single wisdom from various matters; fifth, holding the people of the ten directions in empty space; sixth, holding empty space all entering the people of the ten directions; seventh, holding thoughts entering without shaking; eighth, holding without shaking entering into thoughts; ninth, holding empty space entering into thoughts; tenth, holding thoughts entering into empty space.
Why is it so?
All meritorious dharmas are included in it, and therefore they do not move again.
Eighth, what are the dharmas that the KumÄra-bhÅ«ta Bodhisattvas abide in?
The Bodhisattvas abide in ten things.
What are the ten?

First, the body's actions, speech, and thoughts are all pure and clean. Second, no one can find fault with them. Third, with a single thought, they know where they wish to be reborn. Fourth, they know who has a compassionate mind in the ten directions. Fifth, they know all the trusted people in the ten directions. Sixth, they know all the various kinds of people in the ten directions. Seventh, they know all the activities of people in the ten directions. Eighth, they know the formation and destruction of all lands. Ninth, with spiritual powers and thoughts, they can fly wherever they wish to go. Tenth, they study the purity of all dharmas.
This bodhisattva should further study ten things.
What are the ten things?

First, one should learn to know the buddha-lands; second, one should learn to shake the buddha-lands; third, one should learn to have mastery in one's spiritual powers; fourth, one should learn to see the buddha-lands; fifth, one should learn to go from one buddha-land to another buddha-land; sixth, one should learn to go to innumerable buddha-lands; seventh, one should learn to know innumerable dharmas and ask about them; eighth, one should learn to transform like an illusion and have mastery in one's spiritual powers; ninth, one should learn the Buddha's voice and sound; tenth, one should learn to think of one thing.
One should make offerings to innumerable buddhas and immediately go everywhere.
Why is it so?
It is because entering into one dharma sends out many.
Ninth, what dharmas do the Bodhisattva Yu Alao Sha abide in?
The Bodhisattva attains through ten things.
What are the ten things?

First, they know all the places where beings in the ten directions are born; second, they know all the bonds of affection that beings in the ten directions have; third, they know all the thoughts and past causes of beings in the ten directions; fourth, they know all the good and evil destinies of beings in the ten directions from their past actions; fifth, they know all the various dharmas; sixth, they know all the various transformations that beings in the ten directions think of; seventh, they know all the good and evil destructions of the buddha-lands; eighth, they know all the events of the past, future, and present without limit; ninth, they know all the equal and unequal beings in the ten directions; tenth, they know all the teachings and explanations of the Dharma of space to beings in the ten directions.
The bodhisattvas should also study and know ten kinds of places.
What are the ten kinds of places?

First, one should study the palace of the Buddha's teachings; second, one should study the creation of the palace of the Buddha's teachings; third, one should study what is contained within the Buddha's palace; fourth, one should study the instructions given within the Buddha's palace; fifth, one should study the entrances and exits of the Buddha's palace; sixth, one should study the palace of the Dharma; seventh, one should study the palace of the Dharma King; eighth, one should study the instructions given by the Dharma; ninth, one should study the peaceful practice of the Dharma King; tenth, one should study and follow the instructions given by the Dharma King who creates and transforms.
Why is it so?
The mind gradually enters the great way of the Buddha, and the Dharma that is heard is used for self-instruction.
Ten, what is the Dharma that the bodhisattva at the stage of abhisambodhi abides in?
The bodhisattva enters the ten knowledges and fully discerns and knows them.
What are the ten knowledges?

First, to move countless buddha lands; second, to illuminate countless buddha lands; third, to place countless bodhisattvas in countless buddha lands every day; fourth, to liberate countless people in countless buddha lands every day; fifth, to bring peace to countless beings in countless buddha lands; sixth, to have countless people in the ten directions hear my voice; seventh, to know all the people in the ten directions; eighth, to know the good and evil thoughts of the people in the ten directions; ninth, to bring all the people in the ten directions into the Buddha's path; tenth, to liberate all the people in the ten directions.

The bodhisattva at the stage of 'ready to have no more rebirths' cannot know the body, speech, mind, and actions of the bodhisattva at the stage of 'irreversible,' and cannot know the affairs of the bodhisattva at the stage of 'irreversible.' He cannot know the supernormal powers and thoughts, nor can he know the flying. He also cannot know the past, future, and present affairs of the bodhisattva at the stage of 'irreversible,' nor can he know the buddha-lands that are thought of. He also cannot know the thoughts and actions that are used for wisdom with ten things.

The bodhisattva at the stage of 'ready to have no more rebirths' cannot know the actions of the bodhisattva at the stage of 'irreversible.' This bodhisattva at the stage of 'irreversible' enters the ten knowledges of the Buddha.
What are the ten knowledges?
First, the past, future, and present are suddenly learned from the Buddha; second,
all the Buddha's teachings are fully learned from the Buddha; third, in all Dharma realms there are no obstructions
Fourth, to study from the Buddha the boundless and limitless of all dharmas,
Fifth, to study from the Buddha the merit and spiritual power of protecting all lands with this merit,
Sixth, to study from the Buddha the knowledge of the boundless and limitless of all lands that cannot be counted,

Seventh, to study from the Buddha the peace and security of all buddha lands in the ten directions,ğŸ”½Eighth, to study from the Buddha the practices of all people in the ten directions, Ninth, to study from the Buddha the entry into the wisdom of all dharmas,
Tenth, to study from the Buddha the knowledge of all the wisdom of the buddhas.
Why is it so?

Fully understanding and thoroughly comprehending the wisdom of the Buddha, there is no longer anyone to study the Way from. This is the stage of nonretrogression. The bodhisattvas practice the Way in this way with ten dharmas.
